(X. Yao). Defect engineering has become a promising approach to improve the performance of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts. Non-noble transition metal-based catalysts (TMCs) have shown significant promise as effective alternatives to traditional platinum-group catalysts, attracting considerable attention. However, the industrial application of TMCs in electrocatalytic hydrogen production necessitates further optimization to boost both catalytic activity and stability. This review comprehensively examines the types, fabrication methods, and characterization techniques of various defects that enhance catalytic HER activity. Key advancements include optimizing defect concentration and distribution, coupling heteroatoms with vacancies, and leveraging the synergy between bond lengths and defects. In-depth discussions highlight the electronic structure and catalytic mechanisms elucidated through in-situ characterization and density functional theory calculations. Additionally, future directions are identified, exploring novel defect types, emphasizing precision synthesis methods, industrial-scale preparation techniques, and strategies to enhance structural stability and understanding the in-depth catalytic mechanism. This review aims to inspire further research and development in defect-engineered HER catalysts, providing pathways for high efficiency and cost-effectiveness in hydrogen production. Graphical Abstract This review comprehensively covers the latest advancements in defect strategies for electrocatalysts. It delves into various defect types, preparation methods, characterization techniques, and the underlying catalytic mechanisms. Notably, it systematically discusses key breakthroughs such as optimizing defect concentration and distribution, integrating heteroatoms with vacancies, and leveraging the synergy between bond lengths and defects. Keywords Defect Hydrogen evolution reaction Catalytic mechanism Synergistic catalysis Transition metal-based catalyst 1. Introduction Environmental deterioration and energy crisis drive an unprecedented demand of developing green and sustainable energy in recent years, thus to decarburize and substitute current fossil energy system [1,2]. Hydrogen, being a clean and renewable energy source, features high gravimetric energy density and zero emissions, making it a cornerstone in the transition to clean energy [3–6]. To achieve hydrogen as a fuel, sustainable and scalable hydrogen production is necessary whereas it is still a big challenge. At present, various hydrogen production strategies have been developed, such as the fossil fuels refining, methane steam reforming, biohydrogen production, electrocatalytic water splitting, photocatalytic water splitting, and so on [7]. Electrocatalytic water splitting stands out as one of the most promising hydrogen production technologies due to its flexibility and carbon-free process [8]. To enhance energy conversion efficiency, catalysts with high activity and stability are essential for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). To date, materials based on platinum group metals (PGMs, e.g., Pt and Ru) are considered the most attractive catalysts for HER [9]. But the low reserves coupled with high price seriously restrict their commercial application. In this regard, developing cost-effective HER electrocatalysts is highly imperative to substitute the PGM catalysts. Over the years, there has been a growing focus on finding low-cost, abundant, and efficient HER catalysts as alternatives [4,10]. Earth-abundant non-precious transition metal-based catalysts (TMCs) hold great potential due to their versatile physical and chemical properties, encompassing metal oxides, nitrides, sulfides, carbides, selenides, phosphides, and so on [11–18]. However, the catalytic ability of TMCs for electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reactions is relatively insufficient, primarily due to their low intrinsic performance and/or low active site density [18,19]. To improve energy conversion efficiency and enhance cost-competitiveness, there is an urgent demand for the design and optimization of TMCs. The fundamental attributes of high catalytic activity encompass a high density of catalytic sites, strong intrinsic catalytic activity, and excellent conductivity. Recently, defect modification has emerged as a novel approach and has proven to be an effective strategy for enhancing HER performance of TMCs [20–22]. Defects, referred to as imperfections, play a critical role in solid-state science since they determine a variety of material properties. The introduction of defects can disrupt the periodic arrangement of atoms in a crystal, altering its physicochemical properties and electron distribution, thereby increasing the density of active sites and enhancing conductivity [18,23–26]. Defects of various dimensions have been effectively utilized as highly active sites or efficient promoters in a wide range of catalytic reactions [27–29]. Up to now, massive works on defect strategy have been reported to enhance the intrinsic catalytic ability of TMCs and have made outstanding achievements [30–32]. For example, Gao et al. [33] activate the inert basal and conductivity of MoSe2 for hydrogen evolution via the introduction of vacancy defects. Yao et al. [34] reported that incorporating Cr doping defects into Co4N nanorod arrays significantly enhances the adsorption and dissociation of H2O, optimizes hydrogen adsorption free energy, and exhibits exceptional performance in alkaline hydrogen evolution. Zhong et al. [35] induced the generation of oxygen vacancies and local lattice distortion by octahedral Ni2+ ions doping, which can trigger the electron redistribution of Co3O4 nanoflakes. Electrochemical tests indicated a significant enhancement in the catalytic activity of Ni-Co3O4. These studies demonstrate that defects play a crucial role in enhancing the performance of electrocatalysts. In this review, we focus on the defect modification strategy aimed at enhancing the catalytic activity of TMCs for HER, as shown in Scheme 1 . Firstly, we introduce the types, fabrication methods and characterization of defects. Subsequently, the roles of various are also discussed in the realm of HER. Importantly, further modulating defects to perfect the catalytic activity are also summarized, including the concentration and distribution of defects, the coupling of heteroatoms and vacancies, and the synergy between bond lengths among catalytic atoms and defects. It demonstrates how various defects can be strategically applied to engineer the local atomic and electronic properties of electrocatalysts, thereby enhancing the efficiency of the hydrogen evolution reaction. Eventually, the challenges and outlooks of defect strategy are presented. 2. Category of defects and fabrication strategies 2.1. Classification of defects In solid materials science, defects are broadly classified into four main categories based on their spatial dimensions: zero-dimensional defects, one-dimensional defects, two-dimensional defects, and three-dimensional defects. These categories encompass point defects (e.g., atomic vacancies, doping), line defects (e.g., dislocations), interface defects (e.g., grain boundaries), and volume defects (e.g., spatial lattice disorders) [36–38]. Among them, zero-dimensional defects are widely studied. In this review, our primary focus is on the zero-dimensional defects. 2.2. Construction of defects Up to date, various fabrication methods of defects in different dimensions have been reported, including plasma treatment, high energy ball milling, introduction of sacrificial dopants, chemical reduction, electrochemical reduction and so on. 2.2.1. Plasma treatment Plasma treatment is an efficient and fast method to engrave defect on the surface of catalysts. A plasma is a partially ionized gas generated by supplying a sufficient amount of energy to a gas [39,40]. During interactions between plasma and the surface atoms of a catalyst, energy is transferred from highly energetic ions to the surface atoms. This transfer leads to the breaking of covalent bonds and the ejection of surface atoms, resulting in the formation of defects. Besides, plasma treatment can also result in the exfoliation of layered compounds [41,42]. Note that, the selection of gas source affects the types of defects. Generationally, the introduction of Ar or H2 is applied to create vacancy defect [43–45], while the N2/NH3, O2, PH3 plasma can generate extra doping defect [46–49]. For example, Liu et al. [50] fabricated the defective NiSe2 nanosheets using the Ar plasma engraving approach (Fig. 1(a) ). After Ar plasma treatment, a greatly enhanced electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) signal vibration (g = 2.002) can be observed in the EPR spectra (Fig. 1(b)), confirming the existence of Se vacancies. Qi et al. [51] proposed a novel strategy to simultaneously introduce S doping and P vacancies in NiCoP nanosheets by one-step Ar plasma treatment. In details, sulfur powder and NiCoP nanosheets were placed upstream and downstream in the tubular under Ar flow, then the samples were etched by Ar plasma. As shown in Figs. 1(c) and (d)), the significantly enhanced the signals in EPR spectra and the presence of P in X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) suggest that the P vacancy and S doping are simultaneously incorporated into NiCoP nanosheets by one-step plasma treatment. However, the strong sputtering effect or prolonged processing by the plasma treatment can damage the structure of catalyst severely [54–56]. For example, Ye et al. [52] reported the defect engineered monolayer MoS2 by exposing oxygen plasma. As revealed by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) characterization (Fig. 1(e)), it is found that the cracks appeared in the basal plane with longer exposure time. To weaken the strong sputtering effect, the mild remote hydrogen plasma was applied to engrave anion vacancy onto amorphous molybdenum sulfide (a-MoS x ) without damaging the structure (Fig. 1(f)) [53]. The XPS analysis (Fig. 1(g)) revealed that the stoichiometric formula for a-MoS x treated with H2 plasma was determined as MoS1.7. Simultaneously, the active site numbers of pristine MoS2 and a-MoS x were estimated using the Cu underpotential deposition method. The active site number of a-MoS x was found to be 1.2 × 1017 times greater than that of pristine MoS2, indicating a significant rise in the number of HER active sites after H2 plasma treatment. Mention that, plasma etching, as a surface treatment technique, faces challenges in achieving uniformity when defective catalysts are batch-produced. 2.2.2. High-energy ball milling The high-energy ball milling method is an eco-friendly, straightforward, and reproducible mechanical process that facilitates intentional physical and chemical transformations in powdered materials [57,58]. Under the synergistic effects of impact, shear, and friction, the materials undergo continuous deformation, fracturing, and cold welding during repeated collisions with stainless steel balls. This process results in unique properties, including unpredictable arrangements and defect formation [59]. In addition, high-energy ball milling method can effectively reduce or avoid the use of solvents in material synthesis. Moreover, the scalability characteristic further bestows considerable potential on ball milling in the synthesis of nanomaterials for catalytic applications [60]. Recently, high-energy ball milling method has been reported to synthesize highly efficient catalyst with abundant defects [61–65]. For example, Li et al. [66] reported the fabrication of defective MoS2 nanomesh via high-energy ball milling combined with ultrasonic treatment (Fig. 2(a) ). During ball milling, the MoS2 nanosheets were crushed and sheared into smaller pieces, simultaneously creating defects (S-vacancies). As shown in Fig. 2(b), the morphology of the resulting MoS2, featuring abundant S-vacancies and atomic-sized pores distributed across the basal plane, was observed. In addition, Cheng et al. [67] applied the ball milling method to synthesize NiTiO3/Ni HER catalyst with abundant oxygen vacancy defect (Fig. 2(d)). During ball milling, the raw materials of TiO2 and Ni powders undergo mechanical alloying, resulting in the in-situ formation of NiTiO3 at the interface. The Raman spectra (Fig. 2(e)) of in situ synthesized NiTiO3/Ni revealed the broadening and redshifting of peaks, attributed to the low crystallinity of the grains and irregular distribution of atoms. Besides, the enhanced intensity at 754 cm–1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of the TiO6 octahedra, could be attributed to the formation of vacancies on the surface of NiTiO3 during ball milling. Furthermore, the creation of oxygen vacancies is also revealed by the peak of Ti 2p 3/2 in XPS spectra, negatively shifting from 458.1 to 457.9 eV (Fig. 2(f)). Meanwhile, based on the mole ratio between Ti and O, it was found that the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the in situ synthesized NiTiO3/Ni increased by 12.7%. 2.2.3. Introduction of sacrificial dopants The introduction of sacrificial dopants method is a universal method for fabricating cation vacancy [68–73]. For example, Xin et al. [69] reported the synthesis of Ni3S2-VNi/NF with abundant Ni vacancies via a two-step hydrothermal method and following HCl corrosion method. Firstly, as depicted in Fig. 3(a) , Zn was introduced to synthesize Zn-doped Ni3S2 on Ni foam (Zn-Ni3S2/NF) using hydrothermal method. Then, the Zn atoms were corroded by immersing Zn-Ni3S2/NF into 1 mol L–1 HCl to obtain Ni3S2-VNi/NF. According to the Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge Structure (XANES) analysis (Fig. 3(a)), Ni3S2-VNi exhibits a more pronounced white line and a more positive absorption edge than Ni3S2, indicating a higher valence state and reduced valence electron density at the Ni sites. Further differential charge density analysis (Fig. 3(b)) indicates that the formation of Ni vacancies results in a reduction of electron density around both the Ni atoms and the surrounding S atoms, which facilitates the water dissociation. Similarly, Mg was also employed as a sacrificial dopant to create cationic vacancy defects in FeP (Vc-FeP) via a chemical leaching process [68]. Liang et al. [74] reported a method to fabricate Mo vacancies in Mo2C with etching process. In this method, metallic zinc (Zn) was introduced to the lattice of Mo2C to form Zn−Mo2C via hydrothermal reaction and the following heat treatment under 700 °C. The formation of Mo vacancy was induced via the evaporation of Zn under higher temperature of 900 °C. Lei et al. [75] also reported a strategy for constructing single atomic cation vacancy in MoS2 by using Ni atoms as sacrificial dopants. The fabrication of cation vacancy was achieved by firstly preparing single Ni atoms doped MoS2 (Ni-MoS2), and then immersing Ni-MoS2 into K3[Co(CN)6] solution to dissolute Ni atoms, resulting the formation of monoatomic Mo vacancies. The ICP-OES test demonstrated that the Ni content in the sample decreased from 4.58 wt% to 0.71 wt% after immersion. Besides, the high-angle annular dark field transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images (Figs. 3(c) and (d)) and the corresponding intensity line profiles also confirm the presence of cationic Mo vacancies. Furthermore, the EPR spectra (Fig. 3(e)) show that the intensity of Mo–S bond (g = 2.03) significantly enhanced, further demonstrating the resulting Mo vacancies in MoS2 after immersion. The hard template method employing SiO2 was also reported to create cation vacancy [73]. Typically, as shown in Fig. 3(f), by calcining the mixture of ammonium heptamolybdate, dicyanamide, and SiO2 spheres, Mo2C was deposited on the surface of the SiO2 spheres, resulting in the formation of Mo–O–Si bonds. Then, subsequent hydrofluoric acid (HF) etching to eliminate SiO2 resulted in the formation of Mo x C with embedded Mo vacancies and a macroporous inverse opal-like structure (Mo x C-IOL). The resulting Mo vacancies caused a shift in charge-density distribution and concurrently led to the formation of Mo3+ species in Mo2C, displaying superb intrinsic electrocatalytic activity resembling Pt. 2.2.4. Chemical method Chemical reduction is a commonly used strategy to create defects onto catalysts via adding different reducing reagents. Basically, the reported reducing reagents include NaBH4, N2H4, H2O2, H2, NH3, Al and so on [76–79]. For example, Chen et al. [80] reported the synthesis of S or O vacancies via NaBH4 reduction method (Fig. 4(a) ). According to EPR characterization (Fig. 4(b)), the signal peaks generated at g = 2.003 and 2.004 confirm the existence of the unpaired electron, suggesting that S and O vacancies are created after NaBH4 treatment. Similarly, the H2 reduction method is realized by the reaction between H2 and anions (O, S, N, P…) at high temperatures, generating H2O, H2S, NH3, PH3 and so on, consequently generating corresponding anion vacancies [81–84]. Park et al. [85] prepared a MoSe2 catalyst containing coalesced vacancy defects via annealing under H2 atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 4(c), by elevating the concentration of hydrogen gas, mono-Se vacancy tended to exist within close proximity, leading to the formation of two-Se-vacancy configurations. Song et al. used Al as a reducing agent to generate O vacancies in TiO2 by annealing it with Al powder in an evacuated two-zone furnace [86]. 2.2.5. Electrochemical method Compared to chemical reduction, the electrochemical method is a much gentler approach for creating anion vacancies. The density of these vacancies can be adjusted by controlling the applied voltage/current and processing time [88]. The electrochemical reduction method has been successfully applied to create O vacancies [89], S vacancies [90], and so on. For instance, Swaminathan et al. [87] prepared a defect-rich oxide of TiO1.23 for HER via an electrochemical reduction method. Obviously, the XPS spectra (Fig. 4(d)) show a new peak at a lower binding energy of 455.9 eV, which can be assigned to Ti2+. Further quantitative analysis reveals that Ti2+ constitutes 41% of the surface titanium species. The results reveal that oxygen vacancies were generated during cathodic reduction process. Liu et al. [91] also reported a controllable vacancy strategy via an electrochemical charging and discharging process. In details, during the charge and discharge process, Mn in manganese dioxide underwent a redox reaction, and Mn4+ was reduced to Mn3+. The as-formed Mn3+ will experience disproportionation under alkaline conditions to form Mn2+ and Mn4+ dissolved in the electrolyte, thus resulting in the formation of Mn vacancies. 3. Characterization of defects Advanced characterization techniques are essential for identifying the type and structure of defects. These techniques are fundamental for linking the structure and properties of defective materials and understanding the defect catalytic mechanism. The commonly used characterization techniques can be categorized into electron microscopy techniques and spectroscopy techniques. The former encompasses advanced techniques such as aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy (ACTEM), HAADF-STEM, and XPS. The latter includes methods like X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and EPR. 3.1. Electron microscopy techniques HAADF-STEM and ACTEM can acquire the structure and morphology of the electrocatalyst at the atomic scales, which is used to directly observe the surface defect, including vacancy defect and doping defect. For instance, Zhang et al. [92] reported the fabrication of TiVCO with abundant Ti vacancies via annealing TiO2 and TiC under high temperature (Fig. 5(a) ). To confirm the existence of Ti vacancies, the HAADF-STEM characterization was conducted. As shown in Fig. 5(b), some dark spots at Ti atomic sites were observed in the defective TiVCO. Also, the corresponding intensity profiles of dark spots shown in Fig. 5(c) presented lower intensity profiles, reflecting the formation of Ti vacancies. Yao et al. [42] also reported the single Pt anchored defective CoSe2 via photoreduction method (Fig. 5(d)). The HAADF-STEM measurements are performed to characterize the atomic Pt and its coordination structure. Pt atom possesses a greater atomic number, consequently yielding higher contrast relative to the surrounding Co atoms. As shown in Fig. 5(e), single Pt atoms uniformly disperse across the basal plane of defective CoSe2. Further fast Fourier transformation (FFT) of the selected area in Fig. 5(f) and g reveals that the atomic Pt are captured by selenium (Se) vacancies, occupying cobalt (Co) atop sites and establishing atomically coordinated Pt-Co-Se moieties. 3.2. Spectroscopy techniques The EPR technique is capable of monitoring states containing unpaired electrons, which is useful in describing defects, as many defects contain unpaired electrons [93]. The detected the EPR peak signal identified the accurate defect fingerprinting information corresponding to the type of defect, while the intensity of the peak signal can reflect the density of defect. For example, Wang et al. [94] fabricated the defective MoS2 with single-atom S vacancy by H2O2 treatment. The S vacancies are verified by STEM image, marked with yellow circle (Fig. 6(a) and (b)). As shown in Fig. 6(c), the EPR spectra of all the H2O2 treated MoS2 exhibit the signal at g = 2.009, which can be attributed to the formation of S vacancies. Additionally, the signal intensity increases progressively with the etching duration, confirming that the concentration of S-vacancies is rising. Cation vacancies can also be detected by EPR characterization. For instance, Mo vacancy-rich (Mov) MoP synthesized through HCl etching of Co2P/MoP nanorods (Fig. 6(d)). The EPR spectra MoP with Mo vacancies exhibit a distinctive signal at g = 2.00 (Fig. 6(e)). This signal corresponds to non-metallic radical species originating from the Mo-P dangling bonds, indicating the formation of Mo vacancies post-HCl etching and reflecting the structural changes [95]. Additionally, the EPR technique has also demonstrated efficacy in analyzing heteroatom doping defects in electrocatalysts [96,97]. XPS is a powerful surface analysis method that determines an element's elemental composition, empirical formula, and chemical state [99]. In electrocatalysts, the introduction of vacancies or heteroatoms can alter the electronic structure and chemical environment of catalysts, affecting bonding energy and leading to changes in XPS spectra [100,101]. Guo et al. [102] applied the XPS analysis to reveal the electronic structure of the PtCu nanowire network (NNWs) with Cu vacancies. It is found that, after the introduction of Cu vacancies, the peaks of Pt 4f and Cu 2p shift to a lower energy region, indicating that Pt and Cu atoms acquire electrons from neighboring atoms. Besides, the creation of vacancy defect could alter the the element percentages in the catalysts, thus can be revealed by the XPS quantitative analysis. Duan et al. [98] synthesized the nickel phosphides with and without P vacancy (donated as v-Ni12P5 and p-Ni12P5) through thermal annealing. As compared with p-Ni12P5, the Ni 2p and P 2p spectra displayed that the intensity of Ni-P bonds decreases in v-Ni12P5, suggesting that the P vacancies are successfully introduced (Figs. 6(f) and (g)). Furthermore, based on the deconvolution of high-resolution Ni 2p and P 2p spectra, the phosphorus content in v-Ni12P5 decreased from 36.3 at% (in p-Ni12P5) to 28.8 at% (Fig. 6(h)). XAS, as a core-level spectroscopic technique, operates by inducing excitation of electrons from the core to vacant energy states via X-ray irradiation [103]. This analytical approach is pivotal in elucidating the electronic configurations and coordinative structures of specific elements within materials. In XAS, the acquired spectrum can be partitioned into two distinct regions: the XANES and the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). The XANES region exhibits sensitivity towards discerning oxidation states and electronic energy levels associated with the observed elements. Conversely, the EXAFS region facilitates the interpretation of coordination numbers and bond lengths [104]. For example, He et al. [105] developed a propylene oxide-mediated alkalinization precipitation method for the synthesis of Ni-vacancy-tunable nickel hydroxide catalyst (VNi-α-Ni(OH)2- x). In Fig. 7(a) , the Ni K-edge spectra show a positive energy shift from VNi-α-Ni(OH)2-1 to VNi-α-Ni(OH)2-4 at the adsorption edge (B site), indicating a gradual increase in the average valence state of Ni. Meanwhile, the intensities of the Ni–Ni peaks in EXAFS (Fig. 7(b)) followed the sequence of α-Ni(OH)2-1 > VNi-α-Ni(OH)2-2 > VNi-α-Ni(OH)2-3 > VNi-α-Ni(OH)2-4, indicating a corresponding decrease in coordination number (CN) of Ni. Accordingly, these results revealed the existence of VNi in the synthesized samples and the VNi concentrations can be regulated. Atomic Pt anchored at cationic vacancies of α-Ni x Fe1–x (OH)2 (donated as Pt-Ni2Fe1-24) is also studied by XAS [106]. As depicted in Fig. 7(c), the Pt L3-edge XANES spectra indicate that the intensity of the Pt L3-edge in Pt-Ni2Fe1-24 lies between that of PtO2 and Pt foil, reflecting that the Pt atoms possess a higher positive charge compared to Pt foil and a lower coordination number compared to PtO2. Also, the only peak of Pt–O at 1.6–1.7 Å observed in the EXAFS spectra implied that Pt atoms are existed in an isolated state in Pt-Ni2Fe1-24 (Fig. 7(c)). Furthermore, the absence of Pt–Pt bond in the WT of EXAFS spectra (Fig. 7(e) and (f)) further confirmed the monatomic Pt. 3.3. In situ/operando characterizations By comparison with ex situ characterizations mentioned above, in situ/operando Raman and XAS offer valuable time-resolved spectroscopic data, enabling the monitoring of reaction intermediates and the identification of active species during electrochemical reactions [107]. For example, Qiu et al. [108] applied the in situ Raman spectroscopy to reveal interfacial active phases of catalysts under the HER reaction condition (Fig. 8(a) and (b)). The results demonstrated that the presence of Fe inhibits Ni self-oxidation and accelerates water dissociation into H2 during the HER process, facilitated by the formation of FeOOH and Had-Ni δ+ species (Fig. 8(c)). To unraveling the HER mechanism of MoS2 catalyst, Chen et al. [109] also applied real-time surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) to capture direct spectroscopic evidence of intermediates formed during catalytic processes. The in-situ SERS results unequivocally demonstrate the formation of S–H bonds during the HER process, offering compelling evidence that the sulfur atom in MoS2 serves as the catalytic active site for HER. In situ XAS measurements are conducted to obtain direct evidence pinpointing the origins of active sites. Pattengale et al. [110] prepared the atomic Ni doped 1T-MoS2 (Ni@1T-MoS2) HER catalyst and measured the local bonding and electronic structures at Ni and Mo centers via in situ XAS characterization in both acidic and alkaline media. As shown in Fig. 8(d), the very little changes in shape and edge position for the XANES at Mo K-edge suggest negligible structure or oxidation state changes throughout the catalysis process. In contrast, the Ni-K edge XANES spectra showed significant local structure changes. As shown in Fig. 8(e), the application of potential led to a shift of the edge towards lower energy levels in the first-derivative spectra. Furthermore, despite a reduction in length, the Ni-Mo interaction in the second shell of the Fourier-transformed R-space spectra did not exhibit significant changes (Fig. 8(f)). These results reflect that the intrinsic Ni site in Ni@1T-MoS2 acts as the active site without undergoing significant transformation during catalysis in acidic conditions. Conversely, the application of potential causes a significant change in the XANES spectrum under alkaline conditions. A novel edge feature arises at 8.333 keV in the first-derivative spectrum subsequent to the application of potential (Fig. 8(g)), which is ascribed to the formation of Ni0 species. Additionally, the R-space spectrum without the application of potential exhibits a conspicuous reduction in the distance of the first-shell peak, indicating the formation of Ni–O species alongside the coexistence of Ni–S species. Further application of potential resulted in the broadening of first-shell region in the the R-space, which is assigned to the formation of Ni-Ni coordination by the reduction of Ni to Ni0. In general, operando/in situ Raman/XAS spectroscopy offers real-time analysis capabilities for catalysts, effectively facilitating the monitoring of intermediate formation during electrolysis. The results of these operando/in situ characterizations could provide a profound understanding of the catalytic mechanism, significantly contributing to the design of cost-effective catalysts. However, it lacks the sensitivity required for quantitative analysis of the abundance of each species. Moreover, the significant evolution of gas bubbles at higher potentials could potentially undermine the accuracy of the collected data [111]. 4. Mechanistic and theoretical of HER 4.1. Catalytic mechanisms of HER Generally, the widely accepted HER reaction mechanism occurred at the surface of electrode involves two different reaction pathways, named Volmer-Heyrovsky and Volmer-Tafel pathways (Fig. 9 ) [112,113]. In acidic solution, the first step starts with the adsorption of a proton on the catalyst surface and forms hydrogen intermediates (H*) through the acceptance of an electron (Volmer step). The subsequent process is the desorption step of H2, the pathway of which relies on the coverage of H* on the catalyst surface [114]. At high coverage of H*, the formation of H2 follows the Tafel reaction that two H* couples directly to form a H2 molecules. conversely, at low coverage, the H2 can be formed via the Heyrovský reaction through an isolated H* atom coupling a H+ and an e−. While in alkaline solution, the HER reaction also follows the classical Volmer-Heyrovsky process or the Volmer-Tafel process (Fig. 9). Notably, the alkaline HER starts with the dissociation of H-O-H to generate H*, which is widely recognized as the rate-determining step (RDS) [115]. The catalytic HER steps are summarized in Table 1 . 4.2. Density functional theory (DFT) descriptors for electrocatalysts In all reaction routes, the adsorption of H* (Volmer reaction) is involved. Consequently, the free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔGH*) is commonly used to describe the hydrogen-evolving kinetics [116,117]. According to the Sabatier principle, the ΔGH* should be balanced—neither too negative nor too positive—to optimize the adsorption of H* and the desorption of H2 [118,119]. Therefore, a moderate ΔGH* (close to zero) is preferred to give optimal catalytic performance. In the alkaline condition, as the HER process involves the adsorption and dissociation of water, the water adsorption energy (E ad) and the activation energy of water dissociation (E ac) are also employed as descriptors to evaluate the catalyst's propensity to initiate the reaction [120]. Consequently, catalysts with excellent water dissociation performance, suitable ΔGH*, and faster H2 desorption demonstrate excellent catalytic activity. Meanwhile, these characteristics facilitate the release of the active site promptly without compromising its integrity, thus enhancing the catalyst's lifespan [121]. The d-band center theory is extensively employed to predict the adsorption energies of reactants and intermediates on the surface of metal-based catalysts [122,123]. Specifically, when hydrogen binds to the catalyst, a strong interaction occurs between the hydrogen electrons and the d states of the catalyst. The adsorption capacity is predominantly influenced by the position of the d orbital center of the catalysts’ metal atoms [124]. Consequently, the d-band center theory is a valuable tool for elucidating the relationship between the electronic structure and the adsorption performance of the catalyst. This theory effectively reveals the coordination ability and electrocatalytic performance of a catalyst by analyzing its electronic structures and energy level variations [125,126]. Therefore, achieving an optimal d-band center value is crucial for attaining excellent HER electrocatalytic performance. Additionally, several descriptors are used to validate the HER performance of catalysts and to provide a mechanistic explanation. The Bader charge analysis is extensively used to investigate the bonding environment and charge distribution at catalytic sites, providing insights into the mechanisms of electrocatalysis. By analyzing the differences of charge density, the electron transfer between the electrocatalyst and intermediates can be intuitively visualized. This electron transfer is crucial for understanding the catalytic kinetics related to the adsorption and desorption of intermediates. Additionally, the calculations of the density of states (DOS) can illustrate the metallic conductive properties of catalysts. Furthermore, a high density of states near the Fermi level often correlates with increased catalytic activity. 5. Defect chemistry 5.1. Roles of defect on electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution 5.1.1. Vacancy defects Typically, vacancies in materials comprise cationic vacancies, anionic vacancies, and mixed vacancies. Various methods to create diverse vacancies have been successfully developed to tailor the electrocatalytic activities. The introduction of vacancies can not only increase the density of active sites [127] but also alter the local atomic structure and coordination number [128–130]. The enhancement of HER performance by vacancy occurs through three primary mechanisms: adjusting the electronic structure of active sites, increasing the number of active sites, and enhancing electrical conductivity [88,131]. Such modifications can effectively promote the dissociation of water molecules, balance the binding energy of H*, and consequently accelerate the hydrogen evolution reaction. Table 2 summarizes the advanced HER catalysts enhanced by defect strategies, along with their fabrication and characterization methods. 5.1.1.1. Anion vacancies In recent decades, anion vacancies, such as oxygen [132], sulfur [133], tellurium [134], selenium [135], carbon [136], nitrogen [137] and phosphorus [98] vacancies, have been introduced to enhance the hydrogen evolution performance of catalysts. Transition metal oxides are intensively studied as promising candidates for HER electrocatalysis, with the corresponding oxygen vacancies being commonly adopted due to their low formation energy. For example, tungsten trioxide (WO3) and molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) possess good thermodynamic stability in acidic electrolyte. However, their pristine stoichiometric oxides usually demonstrate unfavorable acidic HER activity due to the undesirable adsorption energy of the atomic hydrogen [138–140]. To optimize the adsorption energy of the atomic hydrogen, Yang et al. [141] reported an activation strategy of introducing oxygen vacancy defect into commercial WO3 via annealing under hydrogen atmosphere (Fig. 10(a) ). The creation of O vacancies can significantly stimulate the catalytic activity of WO2.9, leading to a very low overpotential of 70 mV at 10 mA cm–2 and a small Tafel slope of about 50 mV dec–1. Combined the DFT studies, it is revealed that the introduction of O vacancies can modulate the local atomic structure of W atom, resulting in an optimal hydrogen adsorption energy of 0.01 eV (Fig. 10(b)). To explore the active site of defective NiS2, in situ attenuated-total-reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIRS) measurements were conducted to monitor potential adsorption sites and changes in the binding energies of reaction intermediates [142]. As shown in Fig. 10(c), the presence of S–H peak at a low voltage indicates that the introduced sulfur vacancies can optimize the H* adsorption on S sites. Besides, the creation of anionic (Te) vacancy can improve the bulk conductivity and the electrochemical active surface area of WTe2, which could promote the hydrogen evolution reaction [143]. Coalesced vacancy defects are also reported to improve the catalytic capacity of MoSe2 synthesized by annealing under H2 atmosphere (Fig. 10(d)) [85]. Increasing the concentration of hydrogen gas caused mono-Se vacancies (AV-MoSe2) to cluster closely, resulting in the formation of two-Se-vacancy configurations (CV-MoSe2). Both electrochemical analysis and DFT calculations elucidated that the coalesced Se-vacancies in MoSe2 can simultaneously lower both |ΔGH| and ED (H* diffusion), resulting in a low onset potential and an exceptionally low Tafel slope (Fig. 10(e)). The introduction of anion vacancies can also improve the HER performance via modulating the d-band center of catalytic sites. Liu et al. [50] reported the introduction of selenium vacancies in defective NiSe2 could decrease the local electron density of the Ni atoms around the Se vacancy, negatively shifting the Ni d-band centers (Fig. 10(f)). Consequently, the ΔGH* is weakened, approaching to thermal neutrality. As shown in Fig. 10(g), the resulted defective NiSe2 only demand an overpotential of 91 mV at 10 mA cm–2. 5.1.1.2. Cationic vacancies Constructing metal cation vacancies is also an effective method to activating and improving the intrinsic properties of catalysts by modulating the electronic structure. Cation vacancies can exert similar positive effects on catalysts as anionic vacancies, including facilitating water dissociation, expanding the number of active sites, and improving conductivity. Importantly, cation vacancies tend to be more stable during electrochemical reaction [69,144]. However, due to the relatively larger atomic mass and stronger chemical bonding of cations, fabricating cationic vacancies requires aggressive physical bombardment or chemical etching. Consequently, obtaining high-purity mono-typic cationic vacancies is challenging because of the ubiquitous presence of anionic vacancies and large defects such as cracks and holes. A universal method for fabricating cation vacancy is to introduce sacrificial dopant [68–72]. For example, Ni3S2-VNi/NF catalyst with abundant Ni vacancies was synthesized by using Zn as sacrificial dopant [69]. The EPR spectra in Fig. 11(a) show a significantly stronger resonance EPR signal with g = 2.003 in Ni3S2-VNi, confirming the existence of Ni vacancies. According to XAS (Fig. 11(b)), the creation of Ni vacancies led to a decrease of the electron density around Ni atom around Ni vacancies, which favors the dissociation reaction of H2O molecules on the top sites of Ni and enhance the adsorption of H on the S site, thereby increasing the intrinsic activity. Commonly, Fe-based compounds (e.g., oxides and (oxy)hydroxides) exhibit poor electrocatalytic activities toward HER, which are rarely reported in early literature reports. To empower Fe-based materials, Liu et al. [145] employed the cationic vacancy strategy to activate δ-FeOOH nanosheets (NSs) via introducing Fe vacancies. The incorporation of Fe vacancies can increase the DOS of δ-FeOOH NSs near the Fermi level of both spin components, facilitating the charge transfer capability (Fig. 11(c)). Moreover, the Fe vacancies can activate the Fe2 (its second neighboring surface Fe atom, shown in Fig. 11(d) sites) as catalytically active centers, resulting an optimal ΔGH* for HER. Consequently, the resulted Fe-deficient δ-FeOOH NSs display a low overpotential (η 10) of 108 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is 141mV smaller than that of δ-FeOOH bulk (Fig. 11(e)). 5.1.1.3. Mixed vacancies In addition to the single-type vacancy defects (anion or cation), several recent studies have explored the coexistence of multi-ion vacancies within one material system. Combining multiple vacancies is an efficient strategy to enhance electrocatalytic activity, as it provides abundant extraordinary electrons through the synergistic effects of multiatomic vacancies [131,146]. For example, the MoSe2 with multivacancy is achieved by the Ar2+ beam irradiation [147]. According to the observation by HRTEM (Fig. 12(a) ), four types of vacancies, including single Mo vacancy (VMo), single Se vacancy (VSe), double Se vacancy (VSe2), and the absence of one MoSe2 molecular (VMoSe2), were formed after irradiation. The first-principle calculations have demonstrated that the presence of multivacancies can simultaneously facilitate electronic transfer, increase the number of electrocatalytic sites, and decrease ΔGH*, thereby enhancing the HER performance. Besides ion beam bombardment, methods including memory effect [148], fast jet-electrodeposition [149], galvanostatic electrodeposition [150] and so on, were also validated as the effective strategies for the creation of multivacancies to improve the efficiency of HER. For example, Cai et al. [148] reported the activation of LDH with memory effect, which is realized by hydration of the calcined LDH intermediates (v-NiFe LDH). The decrease in intensity of peaks at 2.05 Å (M–O) and 3.10 Å (M–M), as revealed by pair distribution function analysis (Fig. 12(b)), suggests the coexistence of oxygen and metal vacancy defects in v-NiFe LDH. Furthermore, XAS analysis (Figs. 12(c) and (d)) revealed that the multiple vacancy defects induced by memory effect resulted in the formation of dangling bonds and the structural distortion around the Ni/Fe centers, affecting the coordination number of Ni/Fe. This effect could reduce the surface energy of v-NiFe LDH, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity (Fig. 12(e)). 5.1.2. Heteroatom doping Elemental doping in the host materials is also an ingenious option in promoting the catalytic capacity. The introduction of heteroatoms can effectively tune the electronic structure, increase additional active sites, reduce the kinetic energy barrier, and enhance the wettability properties [4,151]. 5.1.2.1. Metallic doping Metal atoms exhibit a strong chemical affinity with metallic host materials, forming highly homogeneous alloy phases or solid solutions. This has been widely reported to enhance the capacity of electrocatalysts for HER. Doping with metal atoms, particularly 3d transition metals with abundant unpaired d electrons or empty d orbitals, has shown significant improvements in catalytic performance [32]. Up to now, transition metal atoms, including Ni, Co, Fe, Zn, Cu, Pt, Ru, Rh, Pd and etc., are extensively studied to optimize the electrocatalytic HER via doping [4,32,152]. Various methods have been developed accordingly, such as hydrothermal/solvothermal treatment and high-temperature annealing. Typically, transition metal dichalcogenides are a class of materials with a layered structure, which are considered as the promising HER catalysts [153,154]. However, the catalytic activity of transition metal dichalcogenides mainly stems from the uncoordinated atoms at the edges [155]. To activate the inert basal plane, many researchers have employed the doping of transition metal cations, such as Ni [156], Co [157], Zn [158], Mn [159], V [160], Pt [161], Pd [162], Ru [163], and Re [164], to enhance the electrocatalytic HER efficiency. For example, Bao et al. [161] prepared metallic Pt doped MoS2 to triggering the HER activity through a one-pot hydrothermal method. The sub-angstrom resolution HAADF-STEM and EXAFS spectra demonstrated that atomic Pt was successfully doped into 2D MoS2 network by substituting Mo site (Figs. 13(a) and (b) ). Further DFT calculations demonstrated that the incorporating Pt atoms can modify the adsorption behavior of H atoms on neighboring S atoms, thereby enhancing HER activity. He et al. [165] reported an atomic Ru incorporated Ni5P4 catalyst for efficient alkaline HER. The incorporation of atomic Ru can induce the localized structural polarization, favoring the charge transfer and water dissociation. A low overpotential of 54 mV is achieved at a current density of 10 mA cm–2. Sun et al. [166] also fabricate Pt single atoms doped TiO2−X catalyst via the plasma sputtering method (Fig. 13(c)). It is revealed that Pt/TiO2−X catalyst exhibits high intrinsic activity, despite the low loading amount of Pt at 1.69 wt%. Accordingly, the Pt/TiO2−X reached a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with an overpotential of only 95 mV (Fig. 13(d)). In addition, Yang et al. [167] utilized Ni2P as a model catalyst to explore the impact of doping on hydrogen evolution activity. They systematically investigated the effects of various heteroatom dopants, including Sn, Pb, Ti, Nb, V, Li, Cr, Na, Mn, Fe, and Co, through both theoretical calculations and experimental validation. The results found that the Bader charge (ΔQ) and d-band center (ɛ d) on the surface of the doped Ni2P catalyst are linearly correlated with the hydrogen adsorption energy (ΔGH*), shown in Figs. 13(e) and (f)). Among the doping heteroatoms, Fe and Co caused the ɛ d of Ni atom to be located near the optimal region. Combined the experimental validation, it is demonstrated that the Fe and Co-doped Ni2P possessed the optimal HER performance. 5.1.2.2. Nonmetal doping Nonmetal elements, such as C, N, O, S, B, P, and Se, have been widely studied for heteroatom doping as well. The commonly adopted strategy to introduce a nonmetallic dopant into the host catalysts is via heat treatment. Thus, the NH3 [168], O2 [169], H2S (or S powder) [170], boric acid [171] and NaH2PO2 [172] and selenium powder [173] are used as sources of N, O, S, B, P, and Se respectively. For instance, Yu et al. [174] fabricated a P-doped CoSe catalyst through low temperature phosphating using NaH2PO2·H2O as P source. Temperature-dependent XRD patterns and XPS spectra revealed that the P doping can induce the structural phase of CoSe2 change from cubic to orthorhombic phases (Figs. 14(a) and (d) ). Such doping-induced phase-transition provide optimal binding of reaction intermediates at P sites, leading to a lowest overpotential of 104 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. Men et al. [175] also reported the electronic modulation of Co2P by N doping can optimize the adsorption free energies of water (ΔG *H2O) and hydrogen (ΔG *H). The N-doped Co2P demonstrates outstanding HER performance, achieving a current density of 10 mA cm–2 with an overpotential of only 42 mV. Hydrothermal treatment was also reported to synthesize the oxygen incorporated MoS2 ultrathin nanosheet for HER [176]. As illustrated in Figs. 14(c) and (d)), by adjusting the reaction temperatures, controllable disorder and oxygen incorporation can be achieved, which not only increases the concentration of active sites but also modulates the electronic structure. The DFT calculations (Fig. 14(e)) show that oxygen-doped MoS2 possesses much narrower bandgap of 1.30 eV in comparison with 2H-MoS2 (1.75 eV), suggesting that oxygen doping can result in an increased number of charge carriers and enhanced intrinsic conductivity. Similarly, B-doped induced amorphization of NiCo LDH also exhibited extremely efficient catalytic capacity [177]. The HRTEM images confirmed the amorphization of NiCo LDH transforms by NaBH4 reduction (Fig. 14(f)). The as-prepared amorphous NiCo LDH exhibited extremely efficient catalytic capacity, achieving low overpotentials of 286 and 381 mV to deliver current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, respectively, in an alkaline medium. (Fig. 14(g)). Due to the changes of catalysts in morphology or structure during electrochemical process, Fan et al. [178] conducted the in-situ Raman spectroscopy and in situ XANES to reveal the structural changes and uncover the real active sites of S doped Co3O4 on carbon cloth (S-Co3O4/CC). As presented by the in situ XRD patterns in Fig. 14(h), crystallized Co(OH)2 was immediately produced at the potential of 0 mV, and then transferred to metallic Co (hcp) at a reductive bias of −200 mV. At the potential of −250 mV, S-Co3O4/CC could be entirely reduced into Co (donated as S-Co/CC), indicating that the hcp-Co scaffold accounts for the enhanced HER activity. To gain in-depth insights into the structure of active sites, in situ Raman spectra of S−Co/CC under positive potentials were also presented (Figs. 14(i) and (j)). It is revealed that scaffold and strong interaction between Co and S can be retained in a wide potential range, rendering the stable active sites for HER. Moreover, in situ Co K-edge XANES spectra were also conducted to reveal the key role of coordinated S anions in catalyzing HER. As shown in Fig. 14(k), an obvious shift of pre-edge toward lower energy at 0 mV compared to pristine S-Co3O4/CC, indicating the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ occurred at 0 mV. Subsequently, the further reduction of Co2+ is observed when more negative potentials of −100 and −200 mV were applied in a row, confirming the existence of oxidized Co δ+. Combined the in situ XRD and Raman spectra analysis, the true active sites for the HER are the “metallic surface-adparticles” system, which includes a metallic Co scaffold and a sparse coverage of sulfur-coordinated Co δ+ species. 5.1.2.3. Dual-atom substitution The introduction of heteroatoms has been confirmed effectively in promotion of HER by the modified electronic structure, increased number of active sites, optimized adsorption of intermediates, improved conductivity and enhanced wettability. However, single dopant cannot achieve all the above functions simultaneously. Thus, dual-atom substitution is proposed to further regulate the catalytic capacity towards HER. For example. Wang et al. [171] conducted a rational design of NiPS3 catalyst by introducing a series of nonmetal heteroatom (B, C, N, and O) and demonstrated that C,N co-doped NiPS3 demonstrated the highest HER activity, resembling that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst, more than single doping. The experimental results further confirmed the (C,N) co-doped NiPS3 possesses the excellent catalytic performance, exhibiting the lowest overpotential of 53.2 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and moderate ΔGH (Figs. 15(a)−(a) ). Lin et al. [179] prepared nonmetallic heteroatoms of N and P co-doped MoS2 towards HER. It was found that the doping of P atoms could improve the electrocatalytic performance and durability while the N dopants could improve the electrical conductivity. Simultaneously, the specific surface area of MoS2 increased after N/S co-doping accordingly. As a result, these factors collectively contributed to an excellent electrochemical property for HER. In addition, dual-cation doping (Ru and Ni) is also reported to modify the catalytic activity of MoS2 (Fig. 15(d)) [180]. As shown in Fig. 15(e), the XAFS elucidated the distribution of Ru atoms coordinated with sulfur on the Ni top sites. Further analysis of electron density difference (Fig. 15(f)) shows that the electric charge density of Ru in Ru/Ni-MoS2 increased, while the electric charge density of the Ni in Ru/Ni-MoS2 decreased. Combined the theoretical calculations, the the synergistic effect of Ru and Ni in Ru/Ni-MoS2 is illustrated, where Ni atoms acted as hydrogen acceptors and single-atom Ru as hydroxyl acceptors. This effectively reduced the energy barrier for the water dissociation step. Similarly, Qiao et al. [181] explored the origin of activity enhancement of CoO nanorods via Ni and Zn doping. Based on computational and experimental results, it was revealed that the collaboration of Ni and Zn outperformed their individual doping on enhancing HER performance, achieving an overpotentials of 53 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Specifically, the Ni dopants can donate more electrons to their neighboring O atoms compared with Co, creating an optimal surface electronic environment for hydrogen intermediate binding. Meanwhile, Zn dopants within the host oxide significantly enhance bulk electrical conduction, leading to a substantial increase in turnover frequency (TOF) and hydrogen generation current. Beyond the singular operation of cation or anion doping, dual anion-cation substitutions offer a comprehensive approach to regulating atomic arrangement and electronic properties. Deng et al. [182] reported the Se and Co co-doped MoS2 by a one-pot chemical synthesis method. As shown in Figs. 15(g) and (h)), the HAADF-STEM characterizations revealed that Se atoms were covalently doped into the MoS2 lattice by replacing the S atoms while the Co atoms occupied the Mo sites and mainly coordinate with S atoms. The Se/Co co-doping could not only promote the formation of abundant edges via stabilizing the edges, but also change the electronic structures of the S atoms, leading to a favorable hydrogen adsorption free energy for HER (Fig. 15(i)). 5.2. Stability of defects The stability of a catalyst is intricately tied to its active site. Deactivation of the active site can diminish the reaction rate, thereby influencing the overall catalyst's lifespan. Especially in alkaline electrolytes which involve the adsorption and dissociation of water, developing highly stable catalysts is challenging. Qiao et al. [98] reported the manipulation of electronic structure through the creation of phosphorus vacancies (Pv) in Ni12P5. The presence of Pv can abate the hybridization between Ni 3d and P 2p orbitals, allowing electrons to transfer to the Ni and P atoms near Pv. Such electron redistribution can significantly boost the H* desorption step during HER process, thereby alleviating the damage of the intermediate to the catalyst itself. In consequence, the Pv-modified Ni12P5 demonstrated superior stability in a chronoamperometry test lasting up to 504 h without any decay. By incorporating active but less stable catalyst with the highly stable unit to result in a compact and robust structure, is demonstrated as an efficient method to obtain both high catalytic activity and stability. For example, Staszak-Jirkovsky et al. [183] reported the fabrication of robust CoMoS x structure by integrating the higher activity of CoS x building blocks with the higher stability of MoS x units. The CoMoS x retained the robust [Mo3S13] building blocks similar to MoS x . Such structure allows the CoMoS x to maintain high activity while maintaining good stability. By the stability test via potential sweep correlated with ex situ quantitative measurements of the dissolution of Co and Mo, it is found that Co2+ is approximately five times more stable in CoMoS x than in CoS x . The chemical stability and catalytic durability of catalysts also can be improved by P doping [184]. Liu et al. [185] stabilized the CoS2 through the doping of P, which demonstrate a higher durability than CoS2. Combined the XANES spectroscopy measurements and DFT calculations, it is revealed that the incorporation of P can substantially affect the nature of chemical bonding between Co and S/P. The P doping can deplete the anti-bonding e g* orbitals, which strengthens the chemical bonding between Co and ligands, thereby enhancing the material's chemical stability. Decorating vacancy defect with heteroatoms or metal clusters is also an effective method to enhance the stability of catalysts [62,186]. Wang et al. [187] reported the stabilization of O vacancies (Vo) in Co3O4 (Vo-Co3O4) through filling P atoms (P-Co3O4), which can compensate the coordination numbers of Co atoms at Vo. moreover, upon the filling the P atoms, electrons are moved out of the Co 3d states, leaving more tetrahedral Co2+ than octahedral Co3+ in P-Co3O4. The predominance of tetrahedral Co2+ notably reduces the ΔGH* to a favorable value of −0.08 eV compared to Vo-Co3O4 (−0.28 eV). As a result, P-Co3O4 demonstrates exceptional catalytic stability as both an HER and OER catalyst. 6. Perfecting defects via regulations It is indisputable that the incorporation of vacancies or heteroatoms can effectively promote and accelerate the HER reaction by modulating the local electronic structure and increasing the density of active sites. However, in some cases, the sole manipulation of a single defect on a specific catalyst may not maximize the catalytic efficiency. Therefore, further regulations of defects are proposed to perfect local catalytic sites, including density and distribution of defects, and heteroatoms coupling with vacancy defect. 6.1. Density and distribution of defects Generally, the increase of defect concentration can provide more catalytic active sites, thus improving the efficiency of HER. However, the capacity of catalysts is not positively correlated with the concentration of defects; it is also influenced by the distribution and evolution of defects at high concentrations. These changes further regulate the electronic structure of the active site, consequently impacting the hydrogen evolution performance. Therefore, a compromise may exist between the activity of catalysts and the density of defects. Cao et al. [204] presented a comprehensive study elucidating the catalytic sites (edge sites, sulfur vacancies, and grain boundaries) and their density on the hydrogen evolution of MoS2. The results found that both sulfur vacancies and edge sites can enhance the catalytic performance of MoS2, whereas the catalytic activity at grain boundaries is relatively weak. However, from a viability perspective, engineering sulfur vacancies is a more effective strategy than increasing the number of edge sites. Moreover, the catalytic activity of sulfur vacancies significantly relied on the density of the sulfur vacancies. The optimal catalytic activity was observed when the vacancy density was in the range of 7%–10%. However, the underlying mechanism behind the impact of sulfur vacancy concentration on catalytic activity remains undisclosed, and the distribution of sulfur vacancies at high concentrations has yet to be explored. To investigate the synergistic impact of vacancy concentration and distribution on HER properties, Zhang et al. [94] conducted a systemic study of S-vacancy defect on HER activity of MoS2. The DFT calculations based on ΔGH* were conducted to MoS2 models with S-vacancy concentrations varying from 0% to 18.75%, as well as on MoS2 models with the same S-vacancy concentration but with different S-vacancy distribution. Fig. 16(a) presents the free energy versus the reaction coordinates of MoS2 with diverse S-vacancy states. The results indicate that single S-vacancies lead to superior HER performance compared to agglomerated sulfur vacancies when the concentration is below 12.50%. However, at concentrations exceeding 12.50%, the HER performance is dominated by agglomerated sulfur vacancies. The excellent catalytic activity of the MoS2 with a single S-vacancy concentration of 12.50% originates from the optimal ΔGH* value of 0.02 eV and excellent electrical conductivity due to the occupation of highest electronic state density near the Fermi level. Guided by the theoretical calculations, MoS2 with single S-vacancies was synthesized via H2O2 etching. As shown in Fig. 16(b), the homogeneous single S-vacancies were obtained. And the electrochemical test confirmed the best atomic S-vacancy density of 12.11%, which is almost consistent with theoretically predicted optimal value of 12.50% (Fig. 16(c)). Voiry et al. [205] examined the HER activity of defective MoS2 across a broad range of surface sulfur vacancy densities, extending up to 90%. As exhibited in Figs. 16(d) and (e)), with the increase of S-vacancy concentration, it was found that the defect of MoS2 will experience the transformation of atomic ‘point defects’ at low concentrations of surface S vacancies (S:Mo > 1.7) to ‘S stripping’ with large regions of undercoordinated Mo atoms at high concentrations of surface S vacancies (S:Mo < 1.7), which was evidenced by EPR and XPS analysis. Notably, the existence of the two different domains of S-vacancies translate into two different regimes in HER. At both electrolytes, point-defects lead to a rapid increase of the HER activity as confirmed by the TOF and Tafe values (Figs. 16(f) and (g)). In the regime of S-stripping, the S vacancies could further improve the HER performance—albeit at a slower rate in the basic medium—through the formation of domains of undercoordinated Mo. 6.2. Heteroatoms coupling with vacancy defects The heteroatom doping or the creation of vacancy defect itself is an effective strategy to optimize the catalytic performance of nanomaterials. Besides, engineering vacancy defects on a substrate present a promising strategy for effectively stabilizing heteroatoms. This approach also offers the opportunity to create a synergistic effect with heteroatom sites, thereby regulating adsorption, activation, and electron transfer during the catalytic process [206,207]. For example, Cao et al. [208] reported atomic Ru doped MoS2 (SA-Ru-MoS2) electrocatalyst for HER. The introduction of Ru atoms can not only lead to the transition of MoS2 from 2H to 1T phase, but also result in the spontaneous loss of S adjacent to Ru. Fig. 17(a) shows visibly the presence of 1T-MoS2 phases after Ru Doping. The synergy effects of single-atom Ru doping and S vacancy are revealed by DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 17(b), the introduction of single-atom Ru doping coupled with S vacancy results in the loss of electrons near the vacancy and their accumulation in the vicinity of the Ru atom. Such charge redistribution led to the generation of a large gap state in 2H-MoS2 and the increase of the electronic state at the Fermi level in 1T-MoS2 (Fig. 17(c)), which could effectively improve the hydrogen adsorption strength, promote the dissociation of H2O and increase the electrical conductivity. As a result, the atomic Ru doped 1T-MoS2 with S vacancies exhibited the best hydrogen evolution performance in alkaline solution (Fig. 17(d)). The anion vacancy coupled with anion doping can also exert a synergistic effect on catalytic HER performance of MoTe2 [209]. The results demonstrated that Te vacancies can effectively modulate the local electronic structures of Te sites and S sites, which could promote the accumulation of electrons on the surface S atoms, and make the ΔGH* at the S site closest to zero, thus resulting the optimal HER activity. The synergistic modulation of electronic structure of β-Mo2C is also reported by introducing Co doping and Mo-Vacancies to improve the HER performance [101]. Both DFT calculations and experimental results indicate that the chemical states and electronic structures of the molybdenum carbide surface can be modulated by surface Mo vacancies and Co doping, resulting in an increased valence electron concentration around the EF (Fig. 17(e)). Moreover, the d-band center (ɛ d) is modulated, exhibiting a volcano curve between ɛd and specific activity (Fig. 17(f)). Further analysis of charge density distribution (Fig. 17(h)) indicates that alone Co doping induce a strong electron transfer from Co to Mo atom, while the introduction of Mo vacancies can weaken the degree of electron transfer by the shielding effect of Mo vacancies, resulting in the ɛd located at an optimal position that facilitating the adsorption and desorption of H. Consequently, Co doped β-Mo2C coupled with Mo vacancy demonstrate a low overpotential (η 10 = 125 mV), a low onset overpotential (η onset = 27 mV) and a high exchange current density (j 0 = 1.78 × 10−1 mA cm−2) in the acidic media. The formation of cation vacancies is also responsible for the stabilization of and the high loading. Ma et al. [106] reported the synthesis of single-atom Pt-loaded α-NixFe1−x (OH)2 electrocatalysts via a facile in situ oxidization strategy with H2PtCl6. Here, H2PtCl6 was used as precursor and oxidant. Atomic Pt were anchored at in-situ generated iron cationic vacancies during the oxidization of Fe2+, leading to the formation of Pt single atoms doped α-Ni2/3Fe1/3(OH)2, with a maximum loading of ~6.15 wt%. 6.3. The modification of bond length The introduction of defects will definitely alter the electronic structure of active center, thus to regulate the catalytic activity of catalysts. Note that the change of atom-atom bond length can also modify to the electronic structure of active center, resulting in the shift of the d-band center and changes of surface absorption energy [210–212]. In electrocatalytic HER, the changes of bond length in a HER catalyst, according to the d-band theory, can move the d-band center towards the Fermi level, making ΔGH* close to zero. Besides, the electron transfer capability between catalytic active sites and adsorbed hydrogen is significantly improved. In this case, the modification of bond length is also reported to collaborate with defects to optimize the catalytic HER performance [213–218]. A commonly used strategy to alter the atomic bond length of catalysts is to exert strain on catalyst. Norskov et al. [193] firstly reported the optimization of MoS2 via the synergies of S vacancies and bond length modulation. The S-vacancies were created by subjecting MoS2 to argon plasma, while the adjustment of bond length of MoS2 was accomplished through a patterned gold nanocone support via capillary force. Combined the DFT calculations, it is revealed that the introduction of S vacancies can increase the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH*) and the active site density. Further manipulating the bong length of defective MoS2 can shifts the gap states even closer to the Fermi level and leads to optimal ΔGH*. Under the synergistic effect of bond length and S vacancies. The manipulation of bond length has also been effectively validated in transition metal oxides, which are typically considered HER-inactive materials due to their unsuitable hydrogen adsorption energy [219]. The expanded atomic arrangements can lead to the formation of oxygen vacancies in CoO, as well as alter the surface electronic structure (Fig. 18(a) ). As shown in Fig. 18(b), the combined effect of manipulating bond lengths and introducing oxygen vacancies positions the activity of CoO near the peak of the volcano-shaped plot for HER catalysts. The optimal CoO catalyst displays a much decreased overpotential of ~ 73 mV to produce a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 18(c)). The contribution of bond length to the synergistic effect between heteroatom doping and vacancy is also explored in the single-atom Ru doped MoS2 with S vacancy defects (Ru/MoS2) [220]. The modulation of bond length was achieved by tailoring the curvature of MoS2 (Fig. 18(d)), which is accomplished by tuning the ligament size of nanoporous MoS2. As shown in Fig. 18(e), the changes of bond length can be revealed by the right shift of Mo-Mo peaks in FT-EXAFS spectra. Combined DFT calculations, operando XAS, and ambient pressure XPS analysis, it is revealed that, in the Ru/MoS2 without changing the bond length, the synergistic effect between Ru atoms and S vacancies can activate the Ru sites as the active sites, which could promote the dissociation of H2O molecule and the subsequently H−H coupling. After changing the bond length of Ru/MoS2 via bending, Mo sites located below the SVs (denoted as MoSV) are activated, facilitating the capture of reactants (H2O). As a result, the reactant density in the inner Helmholtz plane increased, thus accelerating the mass transfer to Ru sites. Moreover, the electronic structure of single atom Ru is effectively modulated in the bent Ru/MoS2, which could catalyze the H2O dissociation and H−H coupling more effectively (Fig. 18(f)). Consequently, Ru/MoS2, promoted by curvature-induced alterations in bond length, displayed a low overpotential (30 mV) at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, exceeding that of the commercial Ru/C and Pt/C (Fig. 18(g)). 7. Commercial applications of defect-rich HER electrocatalysts For commercial hydrogen production in electrolyzers, the efficient HER catalysts need to be coupled with OER catalysts and assembled in membrane electrodes. The water electrolysis technology can be mainly categorized into three types(Figs. 19(a)−(c) ): alkaline water electrolyzer (AWE), anion exchange membrane water electrolyzer (AEMWE), and proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWE). Despite achieving industrial-scale hydrogen production, AWE still encounters challenges like limited current densities (below 400 mA cm−2), low operating pressure, and low energy efficiency [221]. In contrast, AEMWE and PEMWE are effective techniques for generating hydrogen from alkaline and acidic media, facilitating on-site hydrogen production and enabling an immediate response to hydrogen demand. PEM electrolyzers can produce high-purity hydrogen at low temperature and high current density. However, under corrosive acidic conditions, employing a PEM electrolyzer necessitates the utilization of noble metal-based catalysts. Particularly for OER catalysts, their activity and stability face significant challenges. Currently, the development of non-noble TMCs exhibited great potential in substituting Pt-based catalysts. For example, Zhang et al. [222] reported a S-doped CoSe2 (M-CoSe1.28S0.72) with favorable HER activity in acidic media, comparable to Pt/C catalyst. The activity and stability of M-CoSe1.28S0.72 were examined in realistic PEM electrolyzers by coupling IrO2 in the anode. The PEM electrolyzers were operated at 60 °C with an electrode area of 4 cm−2. As illustrated in the Figs. 19(d) and (e)), M-CoSe1.28S0.72 demonstrates remarkable HER performance comparable to Pt/C, consistently and reliably producing hydrogen at a rate of 1 A cm−2 for over 410 h without any significant voltage increase. The AEM electrolyzer allows the use of non-nobel metals-based catalysts, which can significantly reduce the costs. For example, a bifunctional γ-FeOOH catalyst with enormous Fe vacancies exhibits an exceptionally low overpotential of 320 and 309 mV at 1000 mA cm–2 for the OER and the HER, respectively [223]. Further examination in an industrial-scale AEM electrolyzer (4 cm2) using defective γ-FeOOH (g-FeOOH) as the anode and cathode shows outstanding water splitting performance. As shown in Fig. 19(f), the g-FeOOH assembled membrane electrode (MEA) provided a higher efficiency of 209 mA cm–2 at 2.0 V than that of the MEA of benchmark catalysts (101 mA cm–2 at 2.0 V) at room temperature. Wei et al. [150] reported the scalable preparation of efficient NiFe-based catalyst with multi-vacancy defects for industrial water electrolysis, showing excellent water splitting performance (Figs. 19(g) and (h)). Furthermore, even under simulated industrial conditions of 5.0 M KOH at 60 °C, The AEM electrolyzer maintained stable operation at an industrial-grade current density of 1000 mA cm−2 delivering an output cell voltage of 1.73 V for 200 h (Fig. 19(i)). 8. Conclusions and perspectives Sustainable electrocatalytic water splitting plays a pivotal role in realizing hydrogen economy, and the development of electrocatalysts with low-cost, high-performance and long-term durability is the premise for achieving economic hydrogen production. The transition metal-based nanomaterials show promising potential as HER catalysts, effectively facilitating electrochemical hydrogen production. To the commercial application of TMCs, further regulations to improve the catalytic activity are required. Defect strategy is employed as an effective method to activate the catalytic capacity of TMCs through providing more active sites and regulating the local electronic structure, which can rival or even surpass that of PGMs catalysts. In this review, defect strategy for the modulation of catalysts towards electrocatalytic HER is systemically summarized, including the types of defects, construction methods, and characterization of defects. Besides, this review demonstrates that how various defects can be applied to rationally engineer the local atomic and electronic properties of electrocatalysts for efficient hydrogen evolution reaction. Importantly, further modulation of defects is also introduced for selected catalysts to amplify their catalytic capacity. In spite of the exciting accomplishments obtained, challenges remain in advancing this strategy in electrocatalysis. In future research, key breakthrough points for enhancing HER catalysts through defect engineering could include optimizing defect types, shapes, distribution, and concentration, exploring novel defect types, and integrating multi-defect strategies. Additionally, the stability of catalysts and scalable preparation methods should also be prioritized. Advanced in-situ characterization techniques and computational methods can further elucidate the underlying mechanisms, offering new pathways for catalytic enhancement. By focusing on these areas, researchers can continue to push the boundaries of catalytic performance. The perspectives, combined with challenges, are summarized as follows: (1) Explore novel defect types. The discovery and exploration of novel defect types present a significant opportunity for advancing HER catalysts. Traditional defects, such as vacancies and dislocations, have shown promise, but emerging research suggests that unconventional defects, such as interstitial defects, may offer unique catalytic properties. By systematically investigating these novel defects, researchers can uncover new mechanisms for enhancing catalytic activity and stability. This approach not only broadens the spectrum of defect engineering but also paves the way for creating highly efficient and durable HER catalysts. Exploring novel defect types holds the potential to revolutionize the field of electrocatalysis, providing new avenues for performance improvement and expanding the applicability of defect strategies to other catalytic processes. (2) Control specific defect type, shape, distribution and concentration. It is difficult to create specific defects with current methods, and the shape, distribution, and concentration are also difficult to precisely control. Consequently, the establishment of accurate structure-activity relationship is still a challenge which requires further study. To better assess the intrinsic activity of specific defects and master performance improvement strategies, precision synthesis methods for creating target defects are highly needed for selected materials to be utilized as efficient HER catalysts. At the same time, such precision synthesis methods can also broaden the application of defect strategy in other catalytic reaction fields. (3) Develop industrial methods for preparing catalysts. Though diverse methods have been developed to synthesize defective electrocatalysts for HER, the synthetic procedures are complicated and expensive. For instance, the chemical etching method consumes a large amount of expensive chemical reagents (such as NaBH4 and H2O2) and simultaneously cause substantial material loss during etching. Plasma treatment is not suitable for large-scale preparation due to the fact that plasma can only contact with the catalysts on the surface layer. Although high-energy ball milling can meet the requirements for large-scale preparation, the morphology of the catalysts and control over the types, distribution, and concentration of defects still leave much to be desired Hence, there is still a need to concentrate on the development of advanced material preparation techniques, particularly high-throughput synthesis methods. This ensures that while meeting the demands for cost-effective batch production, superior catalytic performance can be attained. (4) Strengthen the structural stability of catalyst. The robust stability of catalysts is indispensable for their commercial viability. Nevertheless, catalysts are subject to substantial alterations in dynamic environments. Active sites may experience oxidation, reconstruction, or even dissolution, resulting in a decline in catalytic activity. This effect is exacerbated during industrial operations, where the pronounced evolution of gas bubbles can further compromise catalyst stability. Therefore, the delicate design and construction of defect-based catalysts capable of sustaining long-term stability at ampere-level current densities are imperative for the industrial implementation of electrolytic hydrogen production technology. (5) Understand the in-depth catalytic mechanism. A rational and accurate reaction mechanism will provide guidance for the design and synthesis of efficient defect-rich HER electrocatalysts. Unfortunately, even though DFT calculations are applied to simulate and predict the adsorption energy and active sites, the theoretical models may not fully reflect the real catalytic conditions. Theoretical calculations are also constrained by computational capacity and the methodologies employed. Meanwhile, electrocatalysts will experience structural reconstruction and/or surface rearrangement under high current density, which also affects the HER reaction pathway and mechanism. Therefore, integrating DFT calculations with in-situ/operando characterization techniques can offer insights into potential alterations of defects, unraveling the reaction pathway and catalytic mechanism. Mater., 2023, 6, e12441. Xiangdong Yao is a full professor at Sun Yat-sen University. He received his Ph.D. degree in Materials Engineering at the University of Queensland (Australia) in 2005 and was awarded ARC Postdoctoral Fellow and Australian Research Fellow after joining the ARC Centre of Excellence for Functional Nanomaterials at the University of Queensland since 2003. In 2009, he moved to Griffith University as an Associate Professor then was promoted to a full professor as the group leader of Advanced Energy Materials. His group initiated the concept of defect electrocatalysis and pioneered the systematic research of this field. In 2022, Professor Xiangdong Yao joined Sun Yat-sen University, where his research focuses on energy materials and technologies, particularly in the areas of hydrogen energy and catalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Defect engineering has become a promising approach to improve the performance of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts. Non-noble transition metal-based catalysts (TMCs) have shown significant promise as effective alternatives to traditional platinum-group catalysts, attracting considerable attention. However, the industrial application of TMCs in electrocatalytic hydrogen production necessitates further optimization to boost both catalytic activity and stability. This review comprehensively examines the types, fabrication methods, and characterization techniques of various defects that enhance catalytic HER activity. Key advancements include optimizing defect concentration and distribution, coupling heteroatoms with vacancies, and leveraging the synergy between bond lengths and defects. In-depth discussions highlight the electronic structure and catalytic mechanisms elucidated through in-situ characterization and density functional theory calculations. Additionally, future directions are identified, exploring novel defect types, emphasizing precision synthesis methods, industrial-scale preparation techniques, and strategies to enhance structural stability and understanding the in-depth catalytic mechanism. This review aims to inspire further research and development in defect-engineered HER catalysts, providing pathways for high efficiency and cost-effectiveness in hydrogen production.
